title: Requires the annual inspection of manholes, service box covers and utility poles
summary: Requires the annual inspection of manholes, service box covers and utility poles by gas or electric corporations; requires such inspection reports shall be kept by such corporations and subject to the freedom of information law; and provides civil penalties for violations.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2064

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the public service law, in relation to requiring annual
inspections of manholes, service box covers and utility poles

PURPOSE:
This bill requires the annual inspection of manholes, service
box covers and utility poles.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
Section 1 amends the public
service law by
adding a new section 73. It requires that every gas and electric
corporation annually inspect their manholes, service box covers and
utility poles to determine if there is voltage present in them.

The gas and electric corporations shall keep records of the
examination and make them available for public inspection.

Failure to comply with any of these provisions shall result in a civil
penalty up to $1,000 for the first violation and up to an additional
$2,000 for each succeeding violation occurring within a one year
period.

Section 2 enacts this bill on the thirtieth day after it shall become
law.

JUSTIFICATION:
Early this year (January and February
2004), Con Edison
found several "hot spots" citywide - manholes and service box covers
charged with electricity ranging up to 130 volts. An electric shock
from 50 volts of electricity is enough to disrupt a person's heart
beat with as little as one second of contact. Death may result after
minutes of contact. Manhole covers become electrified due to the
corroding of wires from weather conditions compounded by the salt
used to melt ice and snow.

This bill seeks to alleviate the fears that our city streets may be
unsafe to pedestrian traffic. Utility companies have an obligation to
ensure that their utility poles and service boxes are safe for
passersby. Shoddy, quick-fix cables and temporary wiring are
unacceptable.
Annual inspections will require the utility companies to maintain
their service boxes properly. Written inspection records will prove
that the utility company is complying with its inspection requirements.

City residents must feel confident that the metal plates and manhole
covers in their streets are safe. Any future tragedies must be
avoided and the utility companies must be held responsible.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
New bill.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None to the state.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect on the thirtieth day.
